target_text: "It is difficult to define and measure. That’s for sure. I think before agile, there was a great focus on product level quality. Mainly free of defects and meets customer’s needs. I saw in agile a shift toward code quality and a design that responds to change. There is also a continuous improvement of the process effort."

Role.Subject: Geography
Role.positionality:
Five dimensions
- Role Identity: Product Owner
- Intended Study Level: Masters
- Subject (QS): Geography
- Research Interest (NSF): Economics
- Biases/Assumptions: Epistemological (pragmatic-positivist)

Positionality statement
I am a Product Owner pursuing a Master’s in Geography, bringing product strategy, stakeholder coordination, and spatial thinking to my research. I study economic geography to translate spatial-economic patterns into actionable insights for decision-makers. Epistemologically, I lean pragmatic-positivist: I privilege measurable evidence, causal inference, and implementable models, while recognizing their limits. This positionality leads me to frame questions around optimization and user value and to read user responses as requirements, which can underweight lived experience. I mitigate by triangulating quantitative analysis with participatory methods and reflecting on how question framing and responses shape interpretation.

Codebook.role: Qualitative SE Researcher — PhD Candidate (QS: Computer Science & Information Systems; NSF: Human-Centered Computing/Software & Systems; reflexivity: quality as socio-technical, mildly pro-agile)

codebook.justification: Signals construct indeterminacy: [It is difficult to define and measure.]. From a SE/HCI lens, 'quality' is context-contingent and value-laden.
Reframes quality locus: [a shift toward code quality]. This interpretive move prioritizes internal attributes over product-level outcomes.
Values evolvability: [a design that responds to change]. Reflects agile’s emphasis on resilience and maintainability, a contested, subjective ideal.
Endorses kaizen ethos: [a continuous improvement of the process]. Normative belief that process refinement equates to quality, requiring judgment.
